description:
A Chromium-based WPF/WinForms component that can be embedded into your .NET application to display modern web pages built with HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, Silverlight etc.

To be able to use DotNetBrowser, you should obtain a licence by filling a form at https://www.teamdev.com/dotnetbrowser#evaluate
releaseNotes:
HiDPI Displays
In this version, we are glad to introduce the HiDPI Displays support which allows using all DPI-aware modes. The `BrowserView` control is compatible with different DPI awareness modes and renders HTML content with respect to the scale factor.
See https://dotnetbrowser.support.teamdev.com/solution/articles/9000149568-hidpi-displays for more details.

FIPS-compliant
We are FIPS-compliant now! Starting from the version 1.16 it is possible to use DotNetBrowser in environments where the FIPS restriction is enabled.

Fixes:
- The issue when the `KeyDown` event was unable to subscribe in WinForms in the lightweight rendering mode.
- The issue when the `MouseMove`, `MouseEnter` and `MouseExit` events were not forwarded in WinForms in the heavyweight rendering mode.
- The native crash on specific video cards and VMs.
- The issue when a webpage content was rendered with wrong height and width in the lightweight rendering mode.

Improvements:
- The render channel initialization has been improved by preventing script context creation until the client-side Browser instance is created.
- The Printing API has been extended with the ability to get the type of the printed document (PDF or HTML).
- The ability to set `BrowserPreferences.CrashDumpDir` as an empty string in case if customers don't want to store crash dumps.
summary: Solution for integration of Chromium-based component into .NET applications.
title: DotNetBrowser
